original: Majjhima Nikāya 10
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Satipaṭṭhānasutta
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna sutta
translated: The Foundations of Mindfulness

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṁ nāma kurūnaṁ nigamo.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammam nāma kurūnam nigamaḥ
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling among the Kurus at Kammāsadamma.

original: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus thus:

original: “bhikkhavo”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: “Bhikkhus!”

original: “Bhadante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: bhadanta iti te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ
translated: “Venerable sir!” those bhikkhus replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:🔽“Ekāyano ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā, sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya,
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca  eka ayanaḥ bhikkhave maggo sattānam visuddhiyā soka paridevānam samatikkamāya
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya, ñāyassa adhigamāya, nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṁ
analyzed: dukkha domanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya yat idam
translated: “Bhikkhus, this is the direct path for the purification of beings, for the surmounting of sorrow and lamentation, for the disappearance of pain and grief, for the attainment of the true way, for the realisation of Nibbana—namely,

original: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: cattāro sati paṭṭhānā
translated: the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: Katame cattāro?
analyzed: katame cattāro
translated: What are the four?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu dwells contemplating the body as a body, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.

original: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
analyzed: vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He dwells contemplating feelings as feelings, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.

original: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
analyzed: citte citta anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He dwells contemplating (the nature of) the mind in the mind, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, after removing avarice and sorrow regarding the world.🔽

original: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
analyzed: dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He dwells contemplating feelings in feelings mind in mind phenomena in phenomena, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.🔽This is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body.

original: Uddeso niṭṭhito.🔽1. Kāyānupassanā
analyzed: uddesaḥ niṭṭhito  kāya anupassanā
translated: The recitation section is finished.🔽Contemplation of the body

original: 1.1. Kāyānupassanāānāpānapabba
analyzed: kāya anupassanā ānāpāna pabba
translated: Contemplation of the body, the first tetrad

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu abide contemplating the body as a body?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati, pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā, ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.🔽So satova assasati, satova passasati.🔽Dīghaṁ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṁ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā  saḥ satas iva assasati satas iva passasati  dīgham vai assasantaḥ dīgham assasāmi iti pajānāti dīgham vā passasantaḥ dīgham passasāmi iti pajānāti
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu, gone to the forest or to the root of a tree or to an empty hut, sits down; having folded his legs crosswise, set his body erect, and established mindfulness in front of him,🔽breathing in long, he knows “I breathe in long”; or breathing out long, he knows “I breathe out long”;

original: rassaṁ vā assasanto ‘rassaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā passasanto ‘rassaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: rassam vai assasantaḥ rassam assasāmi iti pajānāti rassam vā passasantaḥ rassam passasāmi iti pajānāti
translated: or breathing in short, he knows “I breathe in short”; or breathing out short, he knows “I breathe out short.”

original: ‘Sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
analyzed: sabba kāya paṭisavedī assasissāmi iti sikkhati sabba kāya paṭisavedī passasissāmi iti sikkhati
translated: He trains himself to breathe in and breathe out sensitive to the whole body.

original: ‘Passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
analyzed: passambhayam kāya saṅkhāram assasissāmi iti sikkhati passambhayam kāya saṅkhāram passasissāmi iti sikkhati
translated: He trains himself to breathe in and breathe out calming bodily activity.🔽Just as a skilled turner or his apprentice, when making a long turn, knows he is making a long turn,

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho bhamakāro vā bhamakārantevāsī vā dīghaṁ vā añchanto ‘dīghaṁ añchāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā añchanto ‘rassaṁ añchāmī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave dakkhaḥ bhamakāraḥ vā bhamakāra antevāsī vā dīgham vā añchantaḥ dīgham añchāmi iti pajānāti rassam vā añchantaḥ rassam añchāmi iti pajānāti
translated: or when making a short turn, knows he is making a short turn;

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dīghaṁ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu dīgham vā assasantaḥ dīgham assasāmi iti pajānāti
translated: in the same way, when breathing in long, a bhikkhu knows “I am breathing in long”;🔽or when breathing out long, he knows “I am breathing out long”;

original: dīghaṁ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā assasanto ‘rassaṁ assasāmī’ti
analyzed: dīgham vā passasantaḥ dīgham passasāmi iti pajānāti rassam vā assasantaḥ rassam assasāmi iti
translated: or when breathing in short, he knows “I am breathing in short”;

original: pajānāti, rassaṁ vā passasanto ‘rassaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;🔽‘sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
analyzed: pajānāti rassam vā passasantaḥ rassam passasāmi iti pajānāti 🔽sabba kāya paṭisavedī assasissāmi iti sikkhati sabba kāya paṭisavedī passasissāmi iti sikkhati
translated: or when breathing out short, he knows “I am breathing out short.”🔽He trains himself to breathe in and breathe out sensitive to the whole body.

original: ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
analyzed: passambhayam kāya saṅkhāram assasissāmi iti sikkhati passambhayam kāya saṅkhāram passasissāmi iti sikkhati
translated: he trains himself to breathe in and breathe out calming the bodily formation.

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati;
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati bahiddhā vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: In this way he abides contemplating the body as a body internally, or he abides contemplating the body as a body externally, or he abides contemplating the body as a body both internally and externally.

original: samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati.
analyzed: samudaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati vaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmim viharati
translated: Or else he abides contemplating in the body its arising factors, or he abides contemplating in the body its vanishing factors, or he abides contemplating in the body both its arising and vanishing factors.

original: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti. Yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: atthi kāyo ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya paṭissati mattāya anissito ca viharati na ca kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Or else mindfulness that ‘there is a body’ is simply established in him to the extent necessary for bare knowledge and mindfulness. And he abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.

original: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.🔽Ānāpānapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati  āna apāna pabbam
translated: That is how a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body.🔽The section for recitation on the mindfulness of breathing is finished.

original: 1.2. Kāyānupassanāiriyāpathapabba
analyzed: kāya anupassanā āiriyāpatha pabba
translated: The section on the contemplation of the body in postures

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gacchanto vā ‘gacchāmī’ti pajānāti, ṭhito vā ‘ṭhitomhī’ti pajānāti, nisinno vā ‘nisinnomhī’ti pajānāti, sayāno vā ‘sayānomhī’ti pajānāti.🔽Yathā yathā vā panassa kāyo paṇihito hoti tathā tathā naṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu gacchantaḥ vā gacchāmi iti pajānāti ṭhitaḥ vā ṭhitaḥ asmi iti pajānāti nisinnaḥ vā nisinnaḥ asmi iti pajānāti sa yānaḥ vā sa yānaḥ asmi iti pajānāti  yathā yathā vā panassa kāyaḥ paṇihitaḥ hoti tathā tathā nam pajānāti
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu, when going forward or back, is one who acts with awareness; in looking toward or looking away, he is one who acts with awareness; in flexing or extending his limbs, he is one who acts with awareness; in wearing his robes and carrying his outer robe and bowl, he is one who acts with awareness; in eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting, he is one who acts with awareness; in passing feces and urine, he is one who acts with awareness; in walking, standing, sitting, falling asleep, waking up, talking, and remaining silent, he is one who acts with awareness.🔽In this way he abides contemplating the body as a body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati;🔽samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati.
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati bahiddhā vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati  samudaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati vaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmim viharati
translated: He abides contemplating arising phenomena in the body, or he abides contemplating vanishing phenomena in the body, or he abides contemplating both arising and vanishing phenomena in the body.

original: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti. Yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: atthi kāyo ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya paṭissati mattāya anissito ca viharati na ca kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Or his mindfulness that ‘there is a body’ is maintained to the extent of knowledge and remembrance only. And he abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.

original: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: That is how a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body.🔽“Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu abides contemplating the nature of origination in the body,315 ‘Such is the body, such its origin, such its passing away’; or he abides contemplating the nature of vanishing in the body, ‘Such is the body, its origination is such, its passing away is such’; or he abides contemplating the nature of origination and vanishing in the body, ‘Such is the body, such its origination, such its passing away.’

original: Iriyāpathapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
analyzed: iriyāpatha pabbam
translated: The section on postures is finished.

original: 1.3. Kāyānupassanāsampajānapabba
analyzed: kāya anupassanā sampajāna pabba
translated: … Mindfully Breathing

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti ālokite
translated: Again, a monk is one who acts with clear comprehension when going forward and returning;🔽who acts with clear comprehension when looking ahead and looking aside;

original: vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe🔽sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme
analyzed: vilokite sampajānakārī hoti samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe  sampajāna kārī hoti asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajāna kārī hoti uccāra passāva kamme
translated: who acts with clear comprehension when flexing and extending his limbs; who acts with clear comprehension when wearing his robes and carrying his outer robe and bowl;🔽who acts with clear comprehension when eating, drinking, consuming food, and tasting; who acts with clear comprehension when defecating and urinating;

original: sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajāna kārī hoti
translated: who acts with clear comprehension when walking, standing, sitting, falling asleep, waking up, talking, and remaining silent.

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati …pe…
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati pe
translated: Thus he dwells contemplating the body in the body internally,

original: evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: And so, monks, a monk dwells contemplating the body in the body.

original: Sampajānapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.🔽1.4. Kāyānupassanāpaṭikūlamanasikārapabba
analyzed: sampajāna pabbam 🔽kāya anupassanā paṭikūla manasikāra pabba
translated: The section on clear comprehension is finished.🔽… Contemplating the Disliked

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā, adho kesamatthakā, tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:🔽‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ🔽hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ pittaṁ
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā taca pariyantam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati  atthi imasmin kāye kesāḥ lomā nakhāḥ dantāḥ tacaḥ masam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam vakka  hadayam yakanam kilomakam pihakam papphāsam antam antaguṇam udariyam karīsam pitta
translated: Again, a bhikkhu reviews this very body up from the soles of the feet and down from the top of the hair, bounded by skin, as full of many kinds of impurities thus:

original: semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ubhatomukhā putoḷi pūrā nānāvihitassa dhaññassa, seyyathidaṁ—sālīnaṁ
analyzed: semham pubbaḥ lohitam sedaḥ medaḥ assu vasā kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttanti  seyyathā api bhikkhave ubhatomukhā pūrā nānā vihitassa dhaññassa
translated: ‘In this body there are head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone-marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, pleura, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, excrement, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovic fluid, urine.’

original: vīhīnaṁ muggānaṁ māsānaṁ tilānaṁ taṇḍulānaṁ. Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso muñcitvā paccavekkheyya:
analyzed: vīhīnam muggānam māsānam tilānam taṇḍulāna tam enam cakkhumā purisaḥ muñcitvā paccavekkheyya
translated: Just as though there were a bag open at both ends full of various kinds of grain, such as hill rice, red rice, beans, peas, millet, and white rice, and a man with good eyes were to open it and review it thus:

original: ‘ime sālī ime vīhī ime muggā ime māsā ime tilā ime taṇḍulā’ti.
analyzed: ime sālī ime vīhī ime muggāḥ ime māsāḥ ime tilāḥ ime
translated: ‘These are hill rice, these are red rice, these are beans, these are peas, this is millet, this is white rice’;🔽so too, a bhikkhu reviews this very body…as full of many kinds of impurities.

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā, adho kesamatthakā, tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:🔽‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā …pe… muttan’ti.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā taca pariyantam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati  atthi imasmin kāye kesā lomā pe muttanti
translated: In the same way, a monk reflects on this very body from the soles of the feet on up, from the crown of the head on down, surrounded by skin and full of various kinds of unclean things:

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati …pe…🔽evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati pe  evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: ‘In this body there are head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, tendons, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, pleura, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’🔽In this way he dwells contemplating the body as a body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

original: Paṭikūlamanasikārapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
analyzed: paṭikūla manasikāra pabbam niṭṭhita
translated: This is how a monk dwells contemplating the body as a body.

original: 1.5. Kāyānupassanādhātumanasikārapabba
analyzed: kāya anupassanā dhātu manasikāra pabba
translated: The section on bringing up the repulsive is finished.🔽… Contemplation of the elements

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ yathāṭhitaṁ yathāpaṇihitaṁ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam yathā ṭhitam yathā paṇihitam dhātuso paccavekkhati
translated: Again, a monk reflects on this very body as it is placed or disposed, by way of the elements:

original: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: ‘In this body there are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṁ vadhitvā catumahāpathe bilaso vibhajitvā nisinno assa.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave dakkhaḥ go ghātakaḥ vā go ghātaka antevāsī vā gāvim vadhitvā catu mahāpathe bilasaḥ vibhajitvā nisinnaḥ assa
translated: Just as though a skilled butcher or his apprentice had killed a cow and were seated at the crossroads with it cut up into pieces,

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ yathāṭhitaṁ yathāpaṇihitaṁ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam yathā ṭhitam yathā paṇihitam dhātuso paccavekkhati
translated: In the same way, a monk reflects on this very body from the soles of the feet on up, from the crown of the head on down, surrounded by skin and full of various kinds of unclean things:

original: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the wind element.’

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati …pe…
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati pe
translated: In this way he abides contemplating the body as a body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

original: evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: This is how a monk abides contemplating the body as a body.

original: Dhātumanasikārapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
analyzed: dhātu manasikāra pabbam niṭṭhita
translated: The section on the elements is finished.

original: 1.6. Kāyānupassanānavasivathikapabba
analyzed: kāya anupassanā anavasi vathika pabba
translated: . The section on the unbidden thought

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ ekāhamataṁ vā dvīhamataṁ vā tīhamataṁ vā uddhumātakaṁ vinīlakaṁ vipubbakajātaṁ.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu seyyathā api passeyya sarīram sivathikāya chaḍḍitam eka aha matam vā dvīha matam vā tīha matam vā uddhumātakam vinīlakam vipubbaka jāta
translated: Again, a monk might see a body discarded in a charnel ground—one day, two days, or three days dead—swollen, discolored, and festering.

original: So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam upasaharati
translated: He then compares it to his very own body,

original: ‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.🔽Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati …pe…
analyzed: ayam pi kho kāyaḥ eva dhammo eva bhāvī eva anatītaḥ ti  iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati pe
translated: thinking: ‘This body, too, is of the same nature, has the same qualities, and cannot escape this fate.’🔽In this way he abides contemplating the body as a body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

original: evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: This is how a monk abides contemplating the body as a body.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ🔽kākehi vā khajjamānaṁ kulalehi vā khajjamānaṁ gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṁ kaṅkehi vā
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu seyyathā api passeyya sarīram sivathikāya chaḍḍita  kākehi vā khajjamānam kulalehi vā khajjamānam gijjhehi vā khajjamānam kaṅkehi vā
translated: Again, as if he were to see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground,🔽a skeleton with flesh and blood, connected with sinews …🔽a fleshless skeleton smeared with blood, connected with sinews …🔽a skeleton detached from the flesh and blood, connected with sinews …

original: khajjamānaṁ sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṁ byagghehi vā khajjamānaṁ dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṁ🔽siṅgālehi vā khajjamānaṁ vividhehi vā pāṇakajātehi khajjamānaṁ.🔽So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
analyzed: khajjamānam su nakhehi vā khajjamānam byagghehi vā khajjamānam dīpīhi vā khajjamāna  siṅgālehi vā khajjamānam vividhehi vā pāṇaka jātehi khajjamāna  saḥ imam eva kāyam upasaharati
translated: disconnected bones scattered in all directions—here a bone of the hand, there a foot bone, here a shin bone, there a thigh bone, here a hip bone, there a rib, here a bone of the neck, there the skull …

original: ‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho kāyaḥ eva dhammo eva bhāvī eva anatītaḥ ti
translated: He compares this same body with it thus: ‘This body, too, is of the same nature, it will be like that, it is not exempt from that fate.’

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati …pe…
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati pe
translated: In this way he abides contemplating the body as a body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

original: evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: This is how a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body.🔽Again, as if he were to see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground,

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṁ samaṁsalohitaṁ nhārusambandhaṁ …pe…
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu seyyathā api passeyya sarīram sivathikāya chaḍḍitam aṭṭhika saṅkhalikam samasa lohitam nhāru sambandham pe
translated: a skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, connected with sinews …

original: Aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṁ nimaṁsalohitamakkhitaṁ nhārusambandhaṁ …pe…
analyzed: aṭṭhika saṅkhalikam nimasa lohita makkhitam nhāru sambandham pe
translated: a skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, held together with sinews …

original: Aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṁ apagatamaṁsalohitaṁ nhārusambandhaṁ …pe…🔽Aṭṭhikāni apagatasambandhāni disā vidisā vikkhittāni, aññena hatthaṭṭhikaṁ aññena🔽pādaṭṭhikaṁ aññena gopphakaṭṭhikaṁ aññena jaṅghaṭṭhikaṁ aññena ūruṭṭhikaṁ aññena🔽kaṭiṭṭhikaṁ aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṁ aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṁ aññena
analyzed: aṭṭhika saṅkhalikam apagata masa lohitam nhāru sambandham pe  aṭṭhikāni apagata sambandhāni disā vidisā vikkhittāni aññena hattha aṭṭhikam aññena  pāda ṭṭhikam aññena gopphaka ṭṭhikam aññena jaṅgha ṭṭhikam aññena ūru ṭṭhikam aññena  kaṭi ṭṭhikam aññena phāsuka ṭṭhikam aññena piṭṭhi ṭṭhikam aññena khandha ṭṭhikam aññena
translated: a skeleton without flesh or blood, held together with sinews …

original: gīvaṭṭhikaṁ aññena hanukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena dantaṭṭhikaṁ aññena sīsakaṭāhaṁ.
analyzed: gīva ṭṭhikam aññena hanuka ṭṭhikam aññena danta ṭṭhikam aññena sīsa kaṭāha
translated: the bones detached from the sinews, lying in all directions—here a hand bone, there a foot bone, here a shin bone, there a thigh bone, here a hip bone, there a rib, here a chest bone, there a shoulder bone, here a neck bone, there a jaw bone, here a tooth, there the skull …

original: So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam upasaharati
translated: He compares this body with that one thus:

original: ‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho kāyaḥ eva dhammo eva bhāvī eva anatītaḥ ti
translated: ‘This body, too, is of the same nature, will become that, has not yet become that.’

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati …pe…
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati pe
translated: In this way he abides contemplating the body as a body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.🔽And he abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.

original: evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: That is how a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ, aṭṭhikāni setāni saṅkhavaṇṇapaṭibhāgāni …pe…
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu seyyathā api passeyya sarīram sivathikāya chaḍḍita aṭṭhikāni setāni saṅkha vaṇṇa paṭibhāgāni pe
translated: Again, as if he were to see a body thrown aside in a charnel ground, the bones whitened, the color of shells …

original: Aṭṭhikāni puñjakitāni terovassikāni …pe…
analyzed: aṭṭhikāni puñjakitāni terovassikāni pe
translated: the bones heaped up, a year old …

original: Aṭṭhikāni pūtīni cuṇṇakajātāni.
analyzed: aṭṭhikāni pūtīni cuṇṇaka jātāni
translated: the bones rotted away to a powder,

original: So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam upasaharati
translated: he applies it to this very body (thinking):

original: ‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho kāyaḥ eva dhammo eva bhāvī eva anatītaḥ ti
translated: ‘This body, too, is of the same nature, it will be like that, it is not exempt from that fate.’

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati;
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati bahiddhā vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: Thus he dwells contemplating (the nature of) this body as a body internally, or he dwells contemplating (the nature of) this body as a body externally, or he dwells contemplating (the nature of) this body as a body both internally and externally.

original: samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati.
analyzed: samudaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati vaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmim viharati
translated: Or else he dwells contemplating in the body its arising factors, or he dwells contemplating in the body its vanishing factors, or he dwells contemplating in the body both its arising and vanishing factors.

original: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti. Yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: atthi kāyo ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya paṭissati mattāya anissito ca viharati na ca kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Or else mindfulness that ‘there is a body’ is simply established in him to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. And he dwells independent, not clinging to anything in the world.

original: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.🔽Navasivathikapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati  navasivathika pabbam
translated: That is how a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body.

original: Cuddasakāyānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cuddasa kāya anupassanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The section on the nine cemetery contemplations is finished.🔽The fourteen contemplations of the body are finished.

original: 2. Vedanānupassanā
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā
translated: Contemplation of Feelings

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu abide contemplating feelings as feelings?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.🔽Dukkhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.🔽Adukkhamasukhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sukham vā vedanam vedayamānaḥ sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti  dukkham vā vedanam vedayamānaḥ dukkham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti  adukkham asukham vā vedanam vedayamānaḥ adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti
translated: Here, bhikkhus, when experiencing a pleasant feeling, a bhikkhu understands: ‘I experience a pleasant feeling’;🔽when experiencing a painful feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a painful feeling’;🔽when experiencing a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.’

original: Sāmisaṁ vā sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.🔽Nirāmisaṁ vā sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: sa āmisam vā sukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ sa āmisam sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti 🔽nirāmisam vā sukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ nirāmisam sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti
translated: When experiencing a sensual pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a sensual pleasant feeling’;🔽when experiencing a spiritual pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a spiritual pleasant feeling’;

original: Sāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.🔽Nirāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.🔽Sāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: sa āmisam vā dukkham vedanam vedayamānaḥ sa āmisam dukkham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti  nirāmisam vā dukkham vedanam vedayamānaḥ nirāmisam dukkham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti  sa āmisam vai adukkham asukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ sa āmisam adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti
translated: When he feels a spiritual painful feeling, he knows ‘I feel a spiritual painful feeling.’🔽When he feels a worldly neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling, he knows ‘I feel a worldly neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.’

original: Nirāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: nirāmisam vai adukkham asukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ nirāmisam adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti
translated: When he feels a spiritual neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling, he knows ‘I feel a spiritual neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.’

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati;
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati bahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati
translated: In this way he abides contemplating feelings as feelings internally, or he abides contemplating feelings as feelings externally, or he abides contemplating feelings as feelings both internally and externally.

original: samudayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati.
analyzed: samudaya dhamma anupassī vā vedanāsu viharati vaya dhamma anupassī vā vedanāsu viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī vā vedanāsu viharati
translated: Or else he abides contemplating in feelings their arising factors, or he abides contemplating in feelings their vanishing factors, or he abides contemplating in feelings both their arising and vanishing factors.🔽Or else mindfulness that ‘there are feelings’ is simply established in him to the extent necessary for bare knowledge and mindfulness.

original: ‘Atthi vedanā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti. Yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: atthi vedanā ati vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya paṭissati mattāya anissito ca viharati na ca kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Or else mindfulness that ‘there is a feeling’ is present to him just to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. He abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.

original: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati
translated: That is how a bhikkhu abides contemplating feelings as feelings.

original: Vedanānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Contemplation of Feelings is finished.

original: 3. Cittānupassanā
analyzed: citta anupassanā
translated: 10. Contemplation of the mind

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu citte cittānupassī viharati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu citte citta anupassī viharati
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu abide contemplating the mind in the mind?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.🔽Vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.🔽Sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānāti  vīta rāgam vā cittam vīta rāgam cittam iti pajānāti  sa dosam vā cittam sa dosam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: Here a bhikkhu, when the mind has passion, knows ‘the mind has passion’;🔽when the mind is without passion, he knows ‘the mind is without passion.’🔽When the mind has hate, he knows ‘the mind has hate’;

original: Vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.🔽Samohaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘samohaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.🔽Vītamohaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītamohaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: vīta dosam vā cittam vīta dosam cittam iti pajānāti  sa moham vā cittam sa moham cittam iti pajānāti  vīta moham vā cittam vīta moham cittam iti pajānāti
translated: when the mind is without hate, he knows ‘the mind is without hate.’🔽When the mind has delusion, he knows ‘the mind has delusion’;🔽when the mind is without delusion, he knows ‘the mind is without delusion.’

original: Saṅkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘saṅkhittaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: saṅkhittam vā cittam saṅkhittam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: When the mind is constricted, he knows ‘the mind is constricted’;

original: Vikkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vikkhittaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.🔽Mahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ ‘mahaggataṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: vikkhittam vā cittam vikkhittam cittam iti pajānāti  mahaggatam vā cittam mahaggatam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows a distracted mind as it really is as ‘distracted mind.’🔽He knows an exalted mind as it really is as ‘exalted mind.’

original: Amahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ ‘amahaggataṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.🔽Sauttaraṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sauttaraṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: a mahaggatam vā cittam a mahaggatam cittam iti pajānāti  sauttaram vā cittam sauttaram cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows an unexalted mind as it really is as ‘unexalted mind.’🔽He knows a surpassed mind as it really is as ‘surpassed mind.’

original: Anuttaraṁ vā cittaṁ ‘anuttaraṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.🔽Samāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘samāhitaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.🔽Asamāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘asamāhitaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: anuttaram vā cittam anuttaram cittam iti pajānāti  samāhitam vā cittam samāhitam cittam iti pajānāti  a samāhitam vā cittam a samāhitam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows an unsurpassed mind as it really is as ‘unsurpassed mind.’🔽He knows a concentrated mind as it really is as ‘concentrated mind.’🔽He knows an unconcentrated mind as it really is as ‘unconcentrated mind.’

original: Vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: vimuttam vā cittam vimuttam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows a liberated mind as it really is as ‘liberated mind.’

original: Avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘avimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: a vimuttam vā cittam a vimuttam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows an unliberated mind as it really is as ‘unliberated mind.’

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā citte cittānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā citte cittānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā citte cittānupassī viharati;
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā citte citta anupassī viharati bahiddhā vā citte citta anupassī viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā vā citte citta anupassī viharati
translated: In this way he abides contemplating mind as mind internally, or he abides contemplating mind as mind externally, or he abides contemplating mind as mind both internally and externally.🔽Or else he abides contemplating in mind its arising factors, or he abides contemplating in mind its vanishing factors, or he abides contemplating in mind both its arising and vanishing factors.

original: samudayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṁ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṁ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṁ viharati.
analyzed: samudaya dhamma anupassī vā cittasmiṃ viharati vaya dhamma anupassī vā cittasmiṃ viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī vā cittasmim viharati
translated: or he remains focused on the phenomenon of origination with regard to the mind, on the phenomenon of passing away with regard to the mind, or on the phenomenon of origination & passing away with regard to the mind.

original: ‘Atthi cittan’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti. Yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: atthi cittanti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya paṭissati mattāya anissito ca viharati na ca kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Or else, mindfulness that ‘there is mind’ is present to him just to the extent necessary for knowledge & recollection. And he remains independent, unsustained by not clinging to anything in the world.

original: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu citte cittānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu citte citta anupassī viharati
translated: This is how a monk remains focused on the mind in & of itself.

original: Cittānupassanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Dhammānupassanā
analyzed: citta anupassanā niṭṭhitā  dhamma anupassanā
translated: The contemplation of mind is finished.

original: 4.1. Dhammānupassanānīvaraṇapabba
translated: The Hindrances, Etc.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati
translated: And how does a monk remain focused on mental qualities in & of themselves?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu
translated: There is the case where a monk remains focused on mental qualities in & of themselves with reference to the five hindrances.

original: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu?
analyzed: katham ca pana bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu
translated: And how does a monk remain focused on mental qualities in & of themselves with reference to the five hindrances?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ kāmacchandaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ kāmacchando’ti
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu santam vā ajjhattam kāmacchandam atthi me ajjhattam kāmacchandaḥ uti
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu understands a mind affected by lust as affected by lust,🔽and a mind unaffected by lust as unaffected by lust.

original: pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ kāmacchandaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ kāmacchando’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: pajānāti asantam vai ajjhattam kāmacchandam na atthi me ajjhattam kāmacchandaḥ iti pajānāti
translated: He understands a mind affected by hate as affected by hate,🔽and a mind unaffected by hate as unaffected by hate.

original: yathā ca anuppannassa kāmacchandassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa
analyzed: yathā ca anuppannassa kāmacchandassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca uppannassa
translated: He understands a mind affected by delusion as affected by delusion,🔽and a mind unaffected by delusion as unaffected by delusion.🔽He understands a contracted mind as contracted,🔽and a distracted mind as distracted.

original: kāmacchandassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa kāmacchandassa āyatiṁ
analyzed: kāmacchandassa pahānam hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa kāmacchandassa āyati
translated: He understands an exalted mind as exalted,

original: anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: an uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
translated: and an unexalted mind as unexalted.

original: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ byāpādaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ byāpādo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā
analyzed: santam vai ajjhattam byāpādam atthi me ajjhattam byāpādaḥ iti pajānāti asantam vā
translated: He understands a surpassed mind as surpassed,

original: ajjhattaṁ byāpādaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ byāpādo’ti pajānāti; yathā ca anuppannassa
analyzed: ajjhattam byāpādam na atthi me ajjhattam byāpādaḥ ti pajānāti yathā ca an uppannassa
translated: and an unsurpassed mind as unsurpassed.🔽He understands a concentrated mind as concentrated,

original: byāpādassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa byāpādassa pahānaṁ hoti
analyzed: byāpādassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca uppannassa byāpādassa pahānam hoti
translated: and an unconcentrated mind as unconcentrated.

original: tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa byāpādassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.🔽Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ thinamiddhaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ thinamiddhan’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ
analyzed: tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa byāpādassa āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti  santam vai ajjhattam thinam iddham atthi me ajjhattam thinam iddham ti pajānāti a santa
translated: and how there is a future non-arising of abandoned ill will, that he knows.🔽When sloth and torpor are present in himself, a monk knows ‘there are sloth and torpor in myself’;

original: vā ajjhattaṁ thinamiddhaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ thinamiddhan’ti pajānāti, yathā ca🔽anuppannassa thinamiddhassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa thinamiddhassa
analyzed: vā ajjhattam thinam iddham natthi me ajjhattam thinam iddham ti pajānāti yathā ca  an uppannassa thinamiddhassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca uppannassa thinamiddhassa
translated: or, when sloth and torpor are absent in himself, he knows ‘there are no sloth and torpor in myself.’🔽He knows how there arises sloth and torpor that has not arisen before;🔽he knows how there is an abandoning of sloth and torpor that has arisen;

original: pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa thinamiddhassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: pahānam hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa thinamiddhassa āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
translated: and he knows how there is a non-arising of abandoned sloth and torpor again in the future.

original: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ uddhaccakukkuccaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ uddhaccakukkuccan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: santam vai ajjhattam uddhacca kukkuccam atthi me ajjhattam uddhacca kukkuccanti pajānāti
translated: When agitation and worry are present in himself, a monk knows ‘there are agitation and worry in myself’;

original: asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ uddhaccakukkuccaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ uddhaccakukkuccan’ti
analyzed: asantam vai ajjhattam uddhacca kukkuccam na atthi me ajjhattam uddhacca kukkuccanti
translated: or, when agitation and worry are absent in himself, he knows ‘there are no agitation and worry in myself.’

original: pajānāti; yathā ca anuppannassa uddhaccakukkuccassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā
analyzed: pajānāti yathā ca anuppannassa uddhacca kukkuccassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā
translated: He knows how there arises agitation and worry that has not arisen before;

original: ca uppannassa uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa
analyzed: ca uppannassa uddhacca kukkuccassa pahānam hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa
translated: and the abandoning of arisen agitation and worry, he knows it;

original: uddhaccakukkuccassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccassa āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
translated: and how there is no further appearance in the future of abandoned agitation and worry, he knows it.

original: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ vicikicchaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ vicikicchā’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ
analyzed: santam vai ajjhattam vicikiccham atthi me ajjhattam vicikiccha ati pajānāti a santa
translated: When there is doubt in himself, a monk knows ‘there is doubt in myself’;

original: vā ajjhattaṁ vicikicchaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ vicikicchā’ti pajānāti; yathā ca anuppannāya🔽vicikicchāya uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannāya vicikicchāya pahānaṁ
analyzed: vā ajjhattam vicikiccham na atthi me ajjhattam vicikicchā ati pajānāti yathā ca an uppannāya  vicikicchāyaḥ uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca uppannāya vicikicchāya pahāna
translated: or, when there is no doubt in himself, he knows ‘there is no doubt in myself’;🔽and he knows how there comes to be the arising of unarisen doubt,🔽and how there comes to be the abandoning of arisen doubt,

original: hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnāya vicikicchāya āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnāya vicikicchāya āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
translated: and how there comes to be the non-arising of abandoned doubt again in the future.

original: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati;
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati
translated: Thus he dwells contemplating mental objects in mental objects internally, or he dwells contemplating mental objects in mental objects externally, or he dwells contemplating mental objects in mental objects internally and externally.

original: samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
analyzed: samudaya dhamma anupassī vā dhammesu viharati vaya dhamma anupassī vā dhammesu viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī vā dhammesu viharati
translated: or he abides contemplating both the nature of arising and the nature of vanishing in things.

original: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti. Yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: atthi dhammā ati vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya paṭissati mattāya anissito ca viharati na ca kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Or mindfulness that ‘there are mental phenomena’ is present to him just as far as needed for knowledge and mindfulness. He abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.

original: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu
translated: That is how a bhikkhu abides contemplating mental phenomena as mental phenomena in terms of the five hindrances.

original: Nīvaraṇapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
analyzed: nīvaraṇa pabbam
translated: The section on the hindrances is finished.

original: 4.2. Dhammānupassanākhandhapabba
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā khandha pabba
translated: . The section on contemplation of the five aggregates

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu
translated: Again, a bhikkhu abides contemplating mental phenomena as mental phenomena in terms of the five aggregates affected by clinging.

original: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu?
analyzed: katham ca pana bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu
translated: And how does a bhikkhu abide contemplating mental phenomena as mental phenomena in terms of the five aggregates affected by clinging?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu
translated: Here a bhikkhu thinks:

original: ‘iti rūpaṁ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
analyzed: iti rūpa iti rūpassa samudayaḥ iti rūpassa atthaṅgamaḥ
translated: ‘Such is form, such its origin, such its passing away;

original: iti vedanā, iti vedanāya samudayo, iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo;
analyzed: iti vedanā iti vedanāya samudayaḥ iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo
translated: This is feeling, this is the origin of feeling, this is the ending of feeling;

original: iti saññā, iti saññāya samudayo, iti saññāya atthaṅgamo;
analyzed: iti saññā iti saññāya samudayaḥ iti saññāya atthaṅgamo
translated: this is perception, this is the origin of perception, this is the ending of perception;

original: iti saṅkhārā, iti saṅkhārānaṁ samudayo, iti saṅkhārānaṁ atthaṅgamo;
analyzed: iti saṅkhārāḥ iti samudayaḥ iti saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo
translated: this is (volitional) processes, this is the origin of (volitional) processes, this is the ending of (volitional) processes;

original: iti viññāṇaṁ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti;
analyzed: iti viññāṇaḥ iti viññāṇassa samudayaḥ iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamaḥ ti
translated: this is consciousness, this is the origin of consciousness, this is the ending of consciousness.’

original: iti ajjhattaṁ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati;
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati
translated: In this way he dwells contemplating (the nature of) things in (various) things in regard to himself, or he dwells contemplating (the nature of) things in (various) things in regard to others, or he dwells contemplating (the nature of) things in (various) things in regard to himself and in regard to others,

original: samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
analyzed: samudaya dhamma anupassī vā dhammesu viharati vaya dhamma anupassī vā dhammesu viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī vā dhammesu viharati
translated: or he dwells contemplating the nature of origination in things, or he dwells contemplating the nature of dissolution in things, or he dwells contemplating the nature of origination and dissolution in things.

original: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti. Yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: atthi dhammā ati vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya paṭissati mattāya anissito ca viharati na ca kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Or his mindfulness that ‘there are (various) things’ is maintained to the extent of knowledge and (right) mindfulness, and he dwells independent, and does not grasp at anything in the world.

original: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu.
analyzed: evam pi kho bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu
translated: That is how a bhikkhu abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects in terms of the five aggregates affected by clinging.

original: Khandhapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
analyzed: khandha pabbam
translated: The chapter on the aggregates is finished.

original: 4.3. Dhammānupassanāāyatanapabba
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā āyatana pabba
translated: The chapter on the sense bases

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati chasu ajjhattika bāhiresu āyatanesu
translated: Again, a bhikkhu abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects in the six internal and external sense bases.

original: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu?
analyzed: katham ca pana bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati chasu ajjhattika bāhiresu āyatanesu
translated: And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu abide contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects in the six internal and external sense bases?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhuñca pajānāti, rūpe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cakkhuñca pajānāti rūpe ca pajānāti yat ca tat ubhayam paṭicca
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu understands the eye, he understands forms, and he understands the fetter that arises dependent on both;🔽and he also understands how there comes to be the arising of the unarisen fetter,

original: uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti
analyzed: uppajjati sayojanam tat ca pajānāti yathā ca an uppannassa sayojanassa uppādaḥ hoti
translated: and how there comes to be the abandoning of the arisen fetter,🔽and how there comes to be the future non-arising of the abandoned fetter.🔽He understands the ear, he understands sounds…🔽He understands the nose, he understands odours…🔽He understands the tongue, he understands flavours…🔽He understands the body, he understands tangibles…🔽He understands the mind, he understands mind-objects, and he understands the fetter that arises dependent on both;🔽and he also understands how there comes to be the arising of the unarisen fetter,

original: tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā
analyzed: tat ca pajānāti yathā ca uppannassa sayojanassa pahānam hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā
translated: and how there comes to be the abandoning of the arisen fetter,

original: ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: ca pahīnassa sayojanassa āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
translated: and how there comes to be the future non-arising of the abandoned fetter.

original: Sotañca pajānāti, sadde ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ
analyzed: sotam ca pajānāti sadde ca pajānāti yat ca tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati sayojana
translated: He understands ear and he understands sounds and he understands the fetter that arises dependent on the pair of them.

original: tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā🔽ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa
analyzed: tat ca pajānāti yathā ca anuppannassa sayojanassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā  ca uppannassa sayojanassa pahānam hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa sayojanassa
translated: He understands how there comes to be the arising of the unarisen fetter,🔽and how there comes to be the abandoning of the arisen fetter,

original: āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
translated: and how there comes to be the future non-arising of the abandoned fetter.

original: Ghānañca pajānāti, gandhe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ
analyzed: ghānam ca pajānāti gandhe ca pajānāti yat ca tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati sayojana
translated: He understands nose and he understands odours and he understands the fetter that arises dependent on the pair of them.

original: tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā🔽ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa
analyzed: tat ca pajānāti yathā ca anuppannassa sayojanassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā  ca uppannassa sayojanassa pahānam hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa sayojanassa
translated: He understands how there comes to be the arising of the unarisen fetter,🔽and how there comes to be the abandoning of the arisen fetter,

original: āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
translated: and how there comes to be the future non-arising of the abandoned fetter.

original: Jivhañca pajānāti, rase ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ
analyzed: jivham ca pajānāti rase ca pajānāti yat ca tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati sayojana
translated: He understands tongue and he understands flavours and he understands the fetter that arises dependent on the pair of them.

original: tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā🔽ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa
analyzed: tat ca pajānāti yathā ca anuppannassa sayojanassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā  ca uppannassa sayojanassa pahānam hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa sayojanassa
translated: and he understands how there is an arising of the fetters that have not arisen,🔽and how there is an abandonment of the fetters that have arisen,

original: āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
translated: and how there is a non-arising of the abandoned fetters again in the future.

original: Kāyañca pajānāti, phoṭṭhabbe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ
analyzed: kāyam ca pajānāti phoṭṭhabbe ca pajānāti yat ca tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati sayojana
translated: He understands the body, he understands touch, he understands the fetter that arises dependent on the two of them,

original: tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā🔽ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa
analyzed: tat ca pajānāti yathā ca anuppannassa sayojanassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā  ca uppannassa sayojanassa pahānam hoti tat ca pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa sayojanassa
translated: and he understands how there is an arising of the fetter that has not arisen,🔽and how there is an abandonment of the fetter that has arisen,

original: āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
analyzed: āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti
